questions.text: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma are least likely to present with ______.
questions.solution:
Jaundice is an uncommon sign of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignancy of the liver. It is commonly seen in men aged 50-60 years who present with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, weight loss, and a palpable mass.

Non-specific symptoms of the advanced malignant disease are anorexia, nausea, lethargy. The gross appearance shows unifocal or multifocal or diffusely infiltrative lesions that are paler than the surrounding tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive use is not an independent risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a risk factor for developing hepatic adenoma. 

Although hepatocellular adenoma can undergo malignant transformation, the true risk is low (10%).

Major risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma:

  • Infection:
    • Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis C
  • Toxins/drugs:
    • Alcoholic cirrhosis
    • Aflatoxins
    • Anabolic steroids
  • Genetic:
    • Hemochromatosis
    • α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
  • Immunological:
    • Autoimmune chronic active hepatitis
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Others:
    • Obesity
    • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis
    • Cirrhosis (other causes and idiopathic).

questions.text: Which of the following can be seen with HCC?
questions.solution:
Paraneoplastic syndrome due to hepatocellular carcinoma can manifest as:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Erythrocytosis

Hypercalcemia in patients with HCC is associated with increased renal reabsorption of calcium and increased bone resorption by parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) generated by HCC. 

Less than 1% of cases of HCC manifest with a paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presented with persistent upper abdominal pain and weight loss. Ultrasound revealed a lesion in the right lobe of the liver and contrast-enhanced CT was suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following tumor markers can be elevated in this patient?
  1. Alpha fetoprotein 
  2. PIVKA-2
  3. Alpha-2-macroglobulin
  4. Glypican 
  5. Neurotensin
questions.solution:
Alpha-2-macroglobulin is not a tumor marker of HCC. 

Tumor markers of HCC are:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
    • Normal (<20 ng/mL),
    • Elevated (21–400 ng/mL), and
    • Diagnostic for HCC (>400 ng/mL). 
  • Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonist - II (PIVKA-II) also called des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP)
  • Glypican 3.
  • Neurotensin (in fibrolamellar type)

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, ascites, and weight loss for 6 months. Investigations revealed a thrombus in the portal vein along with invasion from nearby tumor growth. Which of the following conditions can cause this?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has a secondary Budd-Chiari syndrome due to portal vein obstruction by a neighboring invasive lesion. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has the highest tendency to invade the portal vein.

Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the fibrolamellar variant of HCC?

choices.text: Recurrences are seen despite better prognosis
Occur under the age of 35 years
Not commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B infection

questions.solution:
Fibrolamellar variant of HCC is not commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive variant (<5%) of HCC. They occur under the age of 35 years, without any gender predilection or identifiable predisposing conditions. 

It usually presents as a single large, hard 'scirrhous' tumor. The tumor is well-demarcated, encapsulated, and may have a central fibrotic area. Histology shows large polygonal cells embedded in a fibrous stroma forming lamellar structures.

Fibrolamellar HCC has a better prognosis compared to HCC due to high resectability, but recurrences are seen despite this. Lymph node metastasis may be seen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is found to have a well-circumscribed mass in his liver and is suspected to have fibrolamellar HCC. Which of the following tumor markers will be elevated in his condition?
questions.solution:
Neurotensin is the tumor marker of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Neurotensin is a mitogen which induces cell proliferation in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma. There is increased serum unsaturated vitamin B12 binding capacity seen in fibrolamellar HCC which can also aid in diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about alpha-fetoprotein?

choices.text: AFP level does not return back to normal after hepatic resection
Levels  of >400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings is suggestive of HCC
AFP level can be raised in benign conditions

questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level returns to normal after resection.

Alpha-fetoprotein is a glycoprotein that is produced in early fetal life by the liver. It is also produced by a variety of tumors, such as:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma).

AFP is also elevated during the following conditions:

  • Pregnancy and in benign liver disease (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis)
  • Gastrointestinal tract tumors
  • Along with carcinoembryonic antigen in ataxia-telangiectasia

Limitations of AFP include low sensitivity and specificity. It is not specific to HCC and can occur with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal metastases.

Levels >400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings are suggestive of HCC. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not elevated in fibrolamellar HCC.

questions.text:
AFP is used as a tumor marker in which of the following cancers?
  1. Yolk sac tumor
  2. Hepatoblastoma
  3. Cholangiocarcinoma
  4. Fibrolamellar HCC
  5. HCC
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a tumor marker used to detect cholangiocarcinoma or fibrolamellar HCC.

It is produced by a variety of tumors such as:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma).

questions.text:
Which of the following are modalities of treatment in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma?
  1. Radiofrequency ablation
  2. Thermal ablation
  3. Transarterial chemoembolization
  4. Percutaneous ethanol injection 
  5. Liver transplantation
questions.solution:
All of the given modalities can be used for the treatment of HCC.

Treatment options for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC):

  • Surgical
    • Resection (the mainstay of treatment)
    • Orthotopic liver transplantation 
  • Ablative
    • Percutaneous ethanol injection (PEI) (less frequently used nowadays)
    • Thermal ablation (cryotherapy, radiofrequency ablation, microwave, Nd-YAG laser)
  • Transarterial
    • Embolization
    • Chemoembolization
  • Radiotherapy
    • Combination of transarterial and ablative: external beam radiation
  • Systemic
    • Chemotherapy
    • Hormonal
    • Immunotherapy

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with localized hepatocellular carcinoma. He falls into child-pugh class A and his future liver remnant is 22% of the total liver volume. Which of the following will decrease the tumor burden and improve his hepatic functional reserve?

choices.text: Preoperative portal vein embolization followed by resection

questions.solution:
The patient should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization to improve hepatic functional reserve, followed by resection which will decrease the tumor burden.

Portal venous embolization on the side of the tumor will lead to compensatory hypertrophy of the unaffected liver lobe. This improves the volume and function of the future liver remnant (FLR).

Localized hepatocellular carcinoma

  •  Child-Pugh class A: Patients with child-pugh class A should undergo resection of the tumor.
    • Those with low FLR (<30%) should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization followed by resection. Preoperative embolization helps in improving the FLR volume function prior to resection.
    • Those with adequate FLR (>30-40%) can usually tolerate resection alone.
  • Child-Pugh class B/C or portal hypertension: Patients with early-stage HCC and child-Pugh class B/C or portal hypertension should be considered for transplantation.

 Advanced hepatocellular carcinoma

 Patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma are treated with palliative intent. Following are the management options:

  • Drug therapy - Sorafenib/ Sunitinib/ Regorafenib
  • Transarterial chemoembolisation (TACE) and transarterial radioembolisation (TARE) offer the best results in multifocal disease
  • Radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, high-frequency ultrasound therapy are alternative options
  • Patients with extreme deterioration of performance status and liver function should be offered supportive treatment only.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following scoring systems will you not use to assess oncological outcomes of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score is not used to assess the oncological outcome of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. MELD is used to predict the severity of end-stage chronic liver disease.

Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer staging system (BCLC) is the most commonly used scoring system for staging and management of HCC.

The staging or management of HCC is done by the following:

1. Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer staging system (BCLC)

  • Tumor score (TNM)
  • Child-Pugh score
  • Performance score(Barcelona clinic score)

 2. Cancer of the Liver Italian Program (CLIP) 

  • Tumor size
  • Child-Pugh score
  • AFP
  • Portal vein thrombosis

3. OKUDA staging

  • Bilirubin
  • Ascites
  • Tumor size
  • Albumin

4. Chinese University Prognostic Index (CUPI)

Note: MELD can be used in prioritizing HCC patients in need of liver transplants.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding LI-RADS scoring?

choices.text: LI-RADS 2 has an intermediate probability of malignancy
Treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma can be initiated in LI-RADS 5 without biopsy
LI-RADS 3 is an indication for immediate liver biopsy
LI-RADS 4 is definitive of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
LI-RADS 5 indicates a definitive probability(~100%) of  hepatocellular carcinoma. Therefore treatment can be initiated as early as possible without waiting for a biopsy.

Liver Imaging Reporting and Data Systems (LI-RADS) categories 
Category Assessment
LI-RADS 1 Definitely benign
LI-RADS 2 Probably benign
LI-RADS 3 Intermediate probability of malignancy
LI-RADS 4 Probably HCC
LI-RADS 5 Definitely HCC
  • Routine surveillance should be continued for LI-RADS 1, 2. Additional imaging may be required for LI-RADS 2 based on individual risk.
  • LI-RADS 3 should be evaluated by serial imaging every 3-6 months.
  • Evaluation with a biopsy should be done in LI-RADS 4.
  • Since LI-RADS 5 indicates a definitive probability of hepatocellular carcinoma, treatment can be initiated as early as possible without waiting for a biopsy.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retiree was employed for two decades in a plastic industry, where he was exposed to vinyl chloride. He is at an increased risk of developing which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma of the liver is seen in workers who have been exposed to vinyl chloride for prolonged periods.

Angiosarcoma is the most common malignant mesenchymal tumor of the liver. It is a rare and fatal tumor.

They are associated with the following conditions:

  • Hemochromatosis
  • Neurofibromatosis type I
  • Exposure to vinyl chloride, thorium dioxide, and arsenic.

Patients usually present with vague symptoms of abdominal pain, weakness, fatigue, and weight loss. A hepatic bruit is occasionally heard, reflecting the vascular nature of the tumor.

Central hypovascularity, vascular lakes, and peripheral contrast staining on arteriography are suggestive of an angiosarcoma. Biopsy shows the presence of dilated sinusoids lined by atypical endothelial cells.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of poor feeding and abdominal distension. On evaluation, a mass is detected in the liver which is later diagnosed to be a hepatoblastoma. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis
Most cases occur before the age of 3 years
Treatment is surgical resection followed by chemotherapy
Prognosis is extremely poor for pulmonary metastasis

questions.solution:
In hepatoblastoma, 85% of patients with pulmonary metastases can be successfully treated with resection of the hepatic tumor and chemotherapy or resection of the pulmonary metastases.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common primary hepatic tumor of childhood. The median age at presentation is 18 months, and almost all cases occur before 3 years of age. It has been associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

This tumor generally manifests as an asymptomatic mass. Mild anemia and thrombocytosis are commonly found at presentation.

Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in the majority of patients and can serve as a useful marker for therapeutic response.

Treatment includes chemotherapy that can help downstage tumors such that they are amenable to resection. In patients without metastatic disease or the anaplastic variant, long-term survival rates of 60% to 70% can be expected with complete resection.

Staging of pediatric liver tumors:

Stage

Feature

Stage I

No metastases

Tumor completely resected

Stage II

No metastases

Tumor grossly resected with microscopic residual disease, or tumor rupture/spill at the time of surgery

Stage III

No distant metastases

Tumor unresectable or resected with gross residual tumor, or positive lymph nodes

Stage IV

Distant metastases regardless of the extent of liver involvement

questions.text: A woman was diagnosed to have metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK 7 (-), CK20 (+), and CDX-1 (+) IHC markers. Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin for this metastasis?
questions.solution:
Colorectal carcinoma is the most likely primary tumor for the given metastases. Among the given options, cytokeratin 7 is negative only in colon carcinoma.

The most common site of distant metastasis of colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. The lung is the next most common site for metastasis.

questions.text: In patients with colorectal carcinoma, which of the following is not a bad prognostic factor?
questions.solution:
Metachronous lesions are not associated with a bad prognosis in case of liver metastasis from colon carcinoma.

A metachronous cancer is defined as secondary cancer occurring more than 6 months after the index cancer.

Synchronous cancer is defined as two or more neoplasms identified simultaneously in the same patient, or a second tumor identified within six months after the initial diagnosis.

Predictors of poor outcome in colorectal carcinoma with liver metastasis:

  • Lymph-node-positive primary
  • Disease-free interval <12 months
  • More than one tumor
  • Tumor size >5 cm
  • Serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level >200 ng/mL

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not suitable for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
Cholangiocarcinoma is not an indication for a liver transplant.

Orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) for patients with cholangiocarcinoma had very poor results and this treatment strategy has largely been abandoned.

questions.text: What is the most common indication for liver transplant in children?
questions.solution:
The most common indication for liver transplant in children is biliary atresia. 

In biliary atresia, the extrahepatic bile ducts are occluded, causing obstructive jaundice (conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia) and progressive liver fibrosis in early infancy. Liver transplantation is required if not diagnosed and managed early.

(option B) Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a progressive liver failure in young children, associated with marked hepatic copper overload (in excess of 800 μg/g dry weight). Unlike Wilson disease, ICC is associated with normal or elevated ceruloplasmin levels, indicating a defect late in the copper excretory pathway.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. Which of the following is not a parameter in the selection criteria for transplantation?

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.solution:
A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is a case of non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure and jaundice for more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy is one of the parameters in the King's College criteria for liver transplantation.

It includes the following parameters:

Non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure:

  • PT >100 s (INR >6.5)

        or/and

  • Any three of the following:
    • Age <10 years or >40 years
    • Etiology non-A, non-B hepatitis, or idiosyncratic drug reaction
    • Jaundice more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy i.e., not hyperacute
    • PT >50 s (INR > 3.5)
    • Bilirubin > 18 mg/dl (300 μmol/L)

Paracetamol-induced acute liver failure:

  • pH <7.30 (irrespective of the grade of encephalopathy) 

        or/and

  • All three of the following:
    • Prothrombin time >100 s (INR >6.5)
    • Serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dl (300 μmol/L)
    • Grade 3 or 4 hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation is indicated in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: As standby procedure till a suitable donor is found
Acute fulminant liver failure that is irreversible

questions.solution:
Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation (A-OLTX) is indicated in non-cirrhotic metabolic liver disease.

Auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation is a technique where part of the diseased native liver is removed and replaced with a part of the healthy donor liver. This is done so the retained native liver can regenerate. 

In selective cases of acute liver failure, auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation could provide a chance for native liver regeneration and immunosuppression-free life.

Auxillary orthotopic liver transplant is indicated for the following:

  • Patients aged <40 years
  • Reversible fulminant hepatic failure (auxiliary liver transplantation cannot be done in cases of irreversible liver failure) 
  • Non-cirrhotic metabolic liver disease
  • No hemodynamic instability
  • Hyperacute (not in other cases) Liver failure with Acetaminophen overdose.
Total orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX)  Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation (A-OLTX) 

 The entire liver is transplanted 

 Only a portion of the liver is transplanted

Indications:

  • Fulminant hepatic failure (FHF)
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis

Indications:

  • Crigler–Najjar syndrome type I
  • Homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Galactosemia 
  • Hereditary tyrosinemia 
  • Neimann-Pick's disease
Life-long immunosuppression is required. Immunosuppression is required until the native liver regenerates

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins
